intro: Amblyglottis angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leaf amblyglottis, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in umbels, a typical feature of the Apiaceae family. It thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments. Amblyglottis angustifolia is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
